close_symbols: url (parameter contract: non-NULL, NUL-terminated, guarantees at least one character)
explanation:
For checking MISRA rule (no out-of-bounds accesses by <string.h> functions) you must know exactly which string functions are used here and the guarantees about their arguments and buffers:

- strcmp (from <string.h>): ahc_echo calls strcmp(method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET). You must know the strcmp declaration/semantics (requires both arguments be valid NUL-terminated strings) to determine whether this call can read past the referenced objects.

- strlen (from <string.h>): strlen(emsg) is passed to MHD_create_response_from_buffer. strlen requires a NUL-terminated string; you must verify emsg is NUL-terminated before calling strlen to avoid out-of-bounds reads.

- snprintf (from <stdio.h>): snprintf writes into emsg; you must know its standard semantics (that it will not write more than the provided size and will NUL-terminate if size>0) to conclude whether emsg is safely NUL-terminated and no overflow can occur.

- strerror (POSIX/stdlib string routine): used as an argument to snprintf. You must know that strerror returns a NUL-terminated string (and does not modify emsg) so that snprintf usage is safe.

- errno (global): strerror(errno) is invoked; correctness of the diagnostic string depends on errno being set appropriately, but more importantly errno must be a valid integer used with strerror — include errno to trace when snprintf is invoked and what strerror returns.

- MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET (constant string): strcmp compares method against this constant. You must know that this constant is a proper NUL-terminated string and its lifetime is valid.

- method (parameter contract: non-NULL, NUL-terminated): method is an incoming pointer; to determine safety of strcmp you must know the calling convention / framework guarantee that method is non-NULL and NUL-terminated. If method can be NULL or non-terminated, strcmp could read out-of-bounds.

- url (parameter contract: non-NULL, NUL-terminated, at least 1 char): the code computes &url[1] and passes it to fopen. To ensure &url[1] does not read beyond the url object you must know the caller's guarantee about url (non-NULL, NUL-terminated, and that url[0] exists). If url is empty or NULL, &url[1] or indexing could be undefined/out-of-bounds.

- emsg buffer (char emsg[1024]): size and lifetime of this buffer are required to reason about snprintf and subsequent strlen(emsg). The buffer size (1024) and that snprintf is passed sizeof(emsg) are needed to show snprintf cannot write beyond emsg and that strlen is safe.

- MHD_create_response_from_buffer (signature taking size_t length): strlen(emsg) is passed as the length; you must know that the callee expects a length and that passing strlen(emsg) (which counts bytes up to the first NUL) is intended and safe. This ensures no further string operations in the callee will cause out-of-bounds accesses based on the provided length.

- fopen(&url[1]) use (dependency on url contents): opening the file based on &url[1] implies reading url to compute that pointer; you must ensure that computing &url[1] is valid (see url contract above). Also if url contains unexpected characters this could affect later code paths, so the guarantee about url influences safety of any string operations derived from url.

These symbols (functions, buffers, and the caller/framework contracts for method and url) are necessary to decide whether the string-handling calls in ahc_echo (strcmp and strlen) can legally read only within their referenced objects and therefore whether the MISRA C rule is satisfied.
